title: Finding the Inverse
text:
The general process for finding an inverse is as follow:
Given a polynomial function, restrict the domain of a function that is not one-to-one and then find the inverse.
1) Restrict the domain by determining a domain on which the original function is one-to-one.
2) Replace f(x) with $$y$$.
3) Interchange $$x$$ and $$y$$.
4) Solve for $$y$$, and rename the function or pair of function $$f^{-1\left(xight)}$$.
5) Revise the formula for $$f^{-1\left(xight)}$$ by ensuring that the outputs of the inverse function correspond to the restricted domain of the original function.
However, note that in real-world applications, we do not swap the variables when finding inverses. Instead, we change which variable is considered to be the independent variable.

4) Solve for  y , and rename the function or pair of function , f raised to the negative 1 times x power .
5) Revise the formula for , f raised to the negative 1 times x power  by ensuring that the outputs of the inverse function correspond to the restricted domain of the original function.
However, note that in real-world applications, we do not swap the variables when finding inverses. Instead, we change which variable is considered to be the independent variable.

title: Domain
text: Notice that in this question, $$n$$ and C would not be meaningful when they are less than $$0$$. Thus, the domain and range for them are from zero to $$\infty$$.
